segment.source: Domain member Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key (Windows 10)
segment.target: Domain member Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key security policy setting.

segment.source: Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key
segment.target: Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: The Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key policy setting determines whether a secure channel can be established with a domain controller that is not capable of encrypting secure channel traffic with a strong, 128-bit session key.
segment.target: The Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key policy setting determines whether a secure channel can be established with a domain controller that is not capable of encrypting secure channel traffic with a strong, 128-bit session key.

segment.source: Enabling this policy setting prevents establishing a secure channel with any domain controller that cannot encrypt secure channel data with a strong key.
segment.target: Enabling this policy setting prevents establishing a secure channel with any domain controller that cannot encrypt secure channel data with a strong key.

segment.source: Disabling this policy setting allows 64-bit session keys.
segment.target: Disabling this policy setting allows 64-bit session keys.

segment.source: Whenever possible, you should take advantage of these stronger session keys to help protect secure channel communications from eavesdropping and session-hijacking network attacks.
segment.target: Whenever possible, you should take advantage of these stronger session keys to help protect secure channel communications from eavesdropping and session-hijacking network attacks.

segment.source: Eavesdropping is a form of hacking in which network data is read or altered in transit.
segment.target: Eavesdropping is a form of hacking in which network data is read or altered in transit.

segment.source: The data can be modified to hide or change the name of the sender, or it can be redirected.
segment.target: The data can be modified to hide or change the name of the sender, or it can be redirected.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: When enabled on a member workstation or server, all domain controllers in the domain that the member belongs to must be capable of encrypting secure channel data with a strong, 128-bit key.
segment.target: When enabled on a member workstation or server, all domain controllers in the domain that the member belongs to must be capable of encrypting secure channel data with a strong, 128-bit key.

segment.source: This means that all such domain controllers must be running at least Windows 2000 Server.
segment.target: This means that all such domain controllers must be running at least Windows 2000 Server.

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Allows 64-bit session keys to be used.
segment.target: Allows 64-bit session keys to be used.

segment.source: Not defined.
segment.target: Not defined.

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: It is advisable to set Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key to Enabled.
segment.target: It is advisable to set Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key to Enabled.

segment.source: Enabling this policy setting ensures that all outgoing secure channel traffic will require a strong encryption key.
segment.target: Enabling this policy setting ensures that all outgoing secure channel traffic will require a strong encryption key.

segment.source: Disabling this policy setting requires that key strength be negotiated.
segment.target: Disabling this policy setting requires that key strength be negotiated.

segment.source: Only enable this option if the domain controllers in all trusted domains support strong keys.
segment.target: Only enable this option if the domain controllers in all trusted domains support strong keys.

segment.source: By default, this value is disabled.
segment.target: By default, this value is disabled.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.target: Default values

segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.target: | Server type or GPO

segment.target: Default value

segment.target: Default Domain Policy

segment.target: Default Domain Controller Policy

segment.target: Stand-Alone Server Default Settings

segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: DC Effective Default Settings

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: Member Server Effective Default Settings

segment.target: Disabled

segment.target: Client Computer Effective Default Settings

segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: Policy management
segment.target: Policy management

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Restart requirement
segment.target: Restart requirement

segment.source: None.
segment.target: None.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: Group Policy
segment.target: Group Policy

segment.source: Misuse of this policy setting is a common error that can cause data loss or problems with data access or security.
segment.target: Misuse of this policy setting is a common error that can cause data loss or problems with data access or security.

segment.source: You will you be able to join devices that do not support this policy setting to domains where the domain controllers have this policy setting enabled.
segment.target: You will you be able to join devices that do not support this policy setting to domains where the domain controllers have this policy setting enabled.

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: Session keys that are used to establish secure channel communications between domain controllers and member computers are much stronger starting with Windows 2000.
segment.target: Session keys that are used to establish secure channel communications between domain controllers and member computers are much stronger starting with Windows 2000.

segment.source: Whenever possible, you should take advantage of these stronger session keys to help protect secure channel communications from attacks that attempt to hijack network sessions and eavesdrop.
segment.target: Whenever possible, you should take advantage of these stronger session keys to help protect secure channel communications from attacks that attempt to hijack network sessions and eavesdrop.

segment.source: (Eavesdropping is a form of hacking in which network data is read or altered in transit.
segment.target: (Eavesdropping is a form of hacking in which network data is read or altered in transit.

segment.source: The data can be modified to hide or change the sender, or be redirected.)
segment.target: The data can be modified to hide or change the sender, or be redirected.)

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: Enable the Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key setting.
segment.target: Enable the Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key setting.

segment.source: If you enable this policy setting, all outgoing secure channel traffic requires a strong encryption key.
segment.target: If you enable this policy setting, all outgoing secure channel traffic requires a strong encryption key.

segment.source: If you disable this policy setting, the key strength is negotiated.
segment.target: If you disable this policy setting, the key strength is negotiated.

segment.source: You should enable this policy setting only if the domain controllers in all trusted domains support strong keys.
segment.target: You should enable this policy setting only if the domain controllers in all trusted domains support strong keys.

segment.source: By default, this policy setting is disabled.
segment.target: By default, this policy setting is disabled.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: Devices that do not support this policy setting cannot join domains in which the domain controllers have this policy setting enabled.
segment.target: Devices that do not support this policy setting cannot join domains in which the domain controllers have this policy setting enabled.
